hints: The process of growth or increase, typically by the gradual accumulation of additional layers or matter.
A process by which material is added to a tectonic plate or a landmass.
The gradual buildup of continents through geologic processes.
A type of fold in rock layers that is convex upward, like a capital 'A'.
The upward-arching part of a fold.
Geological structure where rock layers dip away from a central axis.
A group or chain of islands clustered together in a sea or ocean.
Hawaii is an example of this.
Often volcanic in origin.
A fine-grained, dark-colored igneous rock.
The most common rock type in the Earth's oceanic crust.
Forms from the rapid cooling of lava.
A large, cauldron-like hollow that forms shortly after the emptying of a magma chamber.
Often forms after a volcanic eruption.
Crater Lake in Oregon is a famous example.
A deep, narrow valley with steep sides.
Often carved by a river over millions of years.
The Grand Canyon is the most famous example.
A fine-grained natural rock or soil material.
Becomes plastic when wet.
Used to make pottery and bricks.
A coarse-grained sedimentary rock.
Composed of rounded gravel and cobbles.
Looks like a mixture of smaller rocks cemented together.
The theory that the Earth's continents have moved over geologic time.
Proposed by Alfred Wegener.
A precursor to plate tectonics.
The innermost layer of the Earth.
Made up primarily of iron and nickel.
Divided into an inner and outer section.
A large bowl-shaped depression.
Can be formed by a meteorite impact or a volcanic eruption.
Mount St. Helens has a prominent one.
The outermost solid shell of a rocky planet.
Divided into oceanic and continental types.
The layer of Earth we live on.
A landform created by deposition of sediment at the mouth of a river.
Often triangular in shape.
The Mississippi River has a famous one.
The physical and chemical changes that turn sediment into rock.
Includes compaction and cementation.
A process that occurs after deposition.
A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock.
Intermediate in composition between granite and gabbro.
Composed of plagioclase feldspar, hornblende, and biotite.
A sheet of rock that is formed in a fracture in a pre-existing rock body.
Often cuts across layers of older rock.
A type of intrusive igneous rock formation.
A type of carbonate rock and a mineral.
A common mineral in the sedimentary rock called dolostone.
Often forms from the alteration of limestone.
The geological process in which earthen materials are worn away.
Caused by wind, water, or ice.
The wearing away of the land.
A fracture in rock where there has been movement and displacement.
The San Andreas is a famous example.
Causes earthquakes.
A group of rock-forming tectosilicate minerals.
Makes up about 60% of the Earth's crust.
A major component of igneous rocks.
A long, narrow inlet with steep sides.
Carved by glacial activity.
Common in Norway and New Zealand.
The preserved remains or traces of ancient life.
Can be found in sedimentary rock.
Evidence of past life on Earth.
A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock.
Compositionally equivalent to basalt.
A key component of the lower oceanic crust.
A foliated metamorphic rock.
Characterized by alternating bands of light and dark minerals.
Forms from the metamorphism of granite.
A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock.
Forms from slowly cooling magma.
Commonly used in countertops.
An area of volcanic activity away from plate boundaries.
Responsible for the formation of the Hawaiian Islands.
Caused by an upwelling of magma from the mantle.
One of the three main rock types.
Formed from the cooling and solidification of molten rock.
Comes from the Latin word for 'fire'.
A period of the Mesozoic Era.
Known as the 'Age of Dinosaurs'.
Came after the Triassic Period.
Molten rock that has erupted onto the Earth's surface.
A source of igneous rock.
What magma is called when it's above ground.
A sedimentary rock composed mainly of calcium carbonate.
Often contains fossils.
The primary rock type of many caves.
The rigid outermost shell of a rocky planet.
Includes the crust and the uppermost mantle.
It is broken into tectonic plates.
Molten rock found beneath the Earth's surface.
Source of igneous rock.
Erupts to become lava.
The layer of the Earth between the crust and the core.
Makes up most of the Earth's volume.
Where convection currents drive plate tectonics.
A metamorphic rock composed of recrystallized carbonate minerals.
Often used in sculpture and architecture.
Forms from the metamorphism of limestone.
One of the three main rock types.
Formed from existing rock subjected to heat and pressure.
Examples include marble and slate.
A naturally occurring, inorganic solid with a specific chemical composition.
The building blocks of rocks.
Quartz and mica are examples.
Accumulated debris and sediment carried by a glacier.
Can form a ridge or mound.
Evidence of past glaciation.
A naturally occurring volcanic glass.
Forms from very rapid cooling of lava.
Often black and smooth.
A type of rock that contains valuable minerals.
Often contains metals like gold, silver, or copper.
Mined for economic purposes.
The process of mountain formation.
Caused by plate tectonics.
The collision of continents leads to this.
The scientific study of life that existed in past geologic periods.
Involves the study of fossils.
A sub-discipline of geology.
A type of volcanic rock that is very light and porous.
Forms when super-heated, highly pressurized rock is ejected from a volcano.
Can float on water.
One of the most abundant minerals in the Earth's continental crust.
Hard and crystalline.
Found in many types of rocks, including granite.
A major fracture in the Earth's crust.
Often where new crust is being formed.
The East African ___ Valley is a famous example.
The continuous process by which rocks are created, changed, and destroyed.
Describes how igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks are related.
Involves processes like weathering, erosion, and metamorphism.
A clastic sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized mineral particles.
Often red or brown in color.
Forms in deserts, rivers, and oceans.
A medium-grade metamorphic rock.
Contains platy mineral grains like mica.
Characterized by its foliation.
Particulate matter that is transported by wind, water, or ice.
Deposition of this material leads to the formation of sedimentary rock.
Sand and silt are examples.
One of the three main rock types.
Formed from the deposition and cementation of material at the Earth's surface.
Examples include sandstone and shale.
An elastic wave generated by an impulse like an earthquake.
Types include P-waves and S-waves.
Travels through the Earth's interior.
A fine-grained sedimentary rock.
Composed of mud that is a mix of clay minerals and tiny fragments.
Often has a layered appearance.
A fine-grained, foliated metamorphic rock.
Formed from the metamorphism of shale.
Often used for roofing tiles.
A branch of geology concerned with the study of rock layers.
Helps determine the relative age of rocks.
The study of strata.
The process where one tectonic plate moves under another.
Occurs at convergent plate boundaries.
Associated with deep ocean trenches and volcanic arcs.
A type of fold in rock layers that is concave upward, like a smile.
The downward-curving part of a fold.
The opposite of an anticline.
The study of the processes that control the structure and properties of the Earth's crust.
Relates to the movement of large plates.
The force that drives continental drift.
A long, narrow depression in the ocean floor.
Formed at a subduction zone.
The deepest parts of the ocean.
A rupture in the crust of a planetary-mass object.
Allows hot lava, volcanic ash, and gases to escape.
Mount Vesuvius is a famous example.
The breaking down of rocks, soil, and minerals.
Caused by contact with the atmosphere, water, and biological organisms.
Can be physical, chemical, or biological.
A rare type of hot spring that is under pressure and erupts.
Old Faithful is a very well-known example.
Found in volcanic areas.
A persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving.
Formed from compressed snow.
Carves U-shaped valleys.
The mineral form of sodium chloride.
Commonly known as rock salt.
Often forms in evaporite deposits.
A common iron oxide mineral.
The principal source of iron ore.
Can be red, black, or silver.
A soft, brown, combustible sedimentary rock.
A low-grade form of coal.
Often referred to as 'brown coal'.
A fine, wind-deposited silt.
Forms fertile soil.
Found in large deposits in China and the American Midwest.
A group of sheet silicate minerals.
Known for its perfect cleavage, forming thin, flaky layers.
A key component in granite.
A conical mound of earth raised by a small, burrowing animal.
A small, hummock-like landform.
A common sight in lawns and fields.
A naturally occurring volcanic glass.
Forms from the rapid cooling of lava.
Black and shiny with a sharp edge.
Ground that remains completely frozen for two or more consecutive years.
Found in polar and high-altitude regions.
Thawing of this can release greenhouse gases.
The branch of geology that studies rocks and the conditions under which they form.
A sub-discipline of geology.
The study of rocks.
A large, high-level area of flat or gently rolling land.
Also known as a tableland.
The Tibetan one is the world's highest and largest.
A dense, malleable, ductile, highly unreactive precious metal.
A rare element in the Earth's crust.
Used in jewelry and catalytic converters.
A body of intrusive igneous rock.
Forms when magma solidifies underground.
The core of a mountain range can be this.
A textural term for an igneous rock with large crystals in a fine-grained matrix.
Often used to describe a type of mineral deposit.
Looks like a 'rock with freckles'.
An iron sulfide mineral.
Also known as 'fool's gold'.
Has a metallic luster and a brassy-yellow hue.
A measure of the bending of a ray of light when passing from one medium into another.
A key property for identifying minerals.
A value that determines how much a substance will slow down light.
An informal term for a depression formed by melting of buried ice.
Can be found in glacial outwash plains.
A type of geological formation.
A medium-grade metamorphic rock.
Often contains abundant mica.
Has a characteristic layered appearance.
A compound containing the sulfide ion, $S^2$.
A common type of mineral, including pyrite.
Often an important ore of metals.
A granular material of a size between sand and clay.
Often found in riverbeds and deltas.
Deposited by water or wind.
A depression or hole in the ground.
Caused by the collapse of the surface layer.
Common in areas with soluble rocks like limestone.
An icicle-shaped formation hanging from the ceiling of a cave.
Formed by the dripping of mineral-rich water.
Often found with its counterpart on the floor.
An upward-growing formation on the floor of a cave.
Formed by mineral deposits from dripping water.
The opposite of a stalactite.
A mineral with a monoclinic crystal structure.
The softest mineral on the Mohs scale.
Often used in cosmetics and baby powder.
Fragmental material produced by a volcanic eruption.
Includes volcanic ash, lapilli, and bombs.
A general term for volcanic ejecta.
A silicate mineral of aluminum and fluorine.
A popular gemstone.
The birthstone for November.
A rock composed of volcanic ash and fragmented rock.
Formed during a volcanic eruption.
A type of igneous rock.
A buried erosional or non-depositional surface.
Represents a gap in the geologic record.
A break in the deposition of sedimentary rock layers.
A sheetlike body of crystallized minerals.
Forms in a fracture or joint in a rock.
Often where precious metals like gold are found.
The central plug of a volcano.
Forms when magma solidifies within the vent.
Shiprock in New Mexico is a famous example.
German geophysicist and meteorologist.
Proposed the theory of continental drift.
His theory was initially dismissed by the scientific community.
A mineral of zirconium silicate.
One of the oldest minerals on Earth.
Used for radiometric dating.
A carbonate mineral and the most stable polymorph of calcium carbonate.
Primary component of limestone.
Has a distinctive rhombohedral cleavage.
A hard, fine-grained sedimentary rock.
Composed of microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline quartz.
Used by ancient peoples to make stone tools.
A combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock.
Formed from the remains of plants.
A major source of energy.
A crystalline form of aluminum oxide.
The mineral that gives us rubies and sapphires.
The second hardest mineral on the Mohs scale.
A solid form of pure carbon.
The hardest known natural mineral.
A valuable gemstone.
A closed depression draining underground.
The most common form of a sinkhole.
Found in karst landscapes.
The point on the Earth's surface directly above the focus of an earthquake.
Where the seismic waves are often strongest.
Determined by seismographs.
A long, winding ridge of stratified sand and gravel.
Deposited by meltwater streams flowing within or under a glacier.
Evidence of past glacial activity.
A flat area of land next to a river.
Formed by the deposition of sediment during floods.
Often very fertile soil.
The planar arrangement of structural features in a metamorphic rock.
Creates a layered or banded appearance.
Seen in rocks like slate and schist.
A piece of mineral crystal that is cut and polished.
Used to make jewelry and other ornaments.
Rubies, emeralds, and sapphires are examples.
A rock cavity lined with crystals.
Often spherical or ovoid in shape.
Hollow inside with a sparkling interior.
Unsorted glacial sediment.
Composed of a wide variety of particle sizes.
Often forms moraines.
A fine-grained, hard, compact metamorphic rock.
Formed by contact metamorphism.
Typically dark-colored.
All the waters on the Earth's surface, such as lakes and seas.
The realm of water on Earth.
Interacts with the lithosphere and atmosphere.
A landscape formed from the dissolution of soluble rocks.
Characterized by sinkholes, caves, and underground streams.
Common in areas with limestone and gypsum.
A type of igneous rock sometimes containing diamonds.
Found in volcanic pipes.
A significant source of diamonds.
The process in which sediments compact under pressure.
Forms a solid rock.
A key part of the rock cycle.
A mineral and one of the main iron ores.
Has a strong magnetic attraction.
Black or brownish-black with a metallic luster.
A qualitative ordinal scale of mineral hardness.
Ranges from 1 (talc) to 10 (diamond).
Used to identify minerals.
A fertile spot in a desert.
Where water is found.
Often formed around a spring.
The supercontinent that existed during the late Paleozoic and early Mesozoic eras.
Broke apart due to plate tectonics.
The name means 'all earth' in Greek.
A type of fossil.
The organic material has been replaced by minerals.
Retains the original structure of the wood.
A hard, non-foliated metamorphic rock.
Formed from pure quartz sandstone.
Resistant to weathering.
A method for determining the age of an object.
Based on the properties of a certain isotope of carbon.
Used to date organic remains up to 50,000 years old.
A linear-shaped lowland.
Formed by the action of a geologic fault.
The East African one is a notable example.
Undulations on the surface of a rock.
Formed in sand or mud by wind, water, or waves.
Evidence of past environments.
A dome-shaped structure in sedimentary rocks.
Formed by the upward movement of a mass of salt.
Often associated with oil and gas deposits.
An instrument used to detect and record seismic waves.
Used to study earthquakes.
Measures ground motion.
Layers of sedimentary rock or soil.
Studied in stratigraphy.
Often seen in canyon walls.
A steep-sided valley cut into the sea floor.
Often found on the continental slope.
Can be larger than terrestrial canyons.
Fissures on the seafloor from which geothermally heated water issues.
Supports unique ecosystems.
Also known as hydrothermal vents.
A type of sedimentary rock formed from glacial till.
Consists of consolidated rock fragments.
Evidence of ancient ice ages.
The study of the forms and features of land surfaces.
The arrangement of the natural and artificial physical features of an area.
Includes hills, valleys, and rivers.
A type of rock made of volcanic ash.
Formed from the ejection of volcanic material.
A type of igneous rock.
A chain of volcanoes.
Forms above a subducting plate.
Examples include the Andes and the Aleutian Islands.
A mass of molten rock ejected during a volcanic eruption.
Cool and solidify before they reach the ground.
Larger than lapilli.
A piece of rock found within another rock.
Often found in igneous rock, but not derived from the original magma.
Means 'foreign rock' in Greek.
A process of erosion.
Caused by the wearing away of rock by transported particles.
Can be caused by wind, water, or ice.
A mass of sediment that is scraped off a subducting plate.
Forms a prism-shaped body of rock.
Located at a subduction zone.
A fan-shaped deposit of sediment.
Forms at the base of a mountain range.
Created by a stream that exits a narrow valley.
A purple variety of quartz.
A popular gemstone.
The birthstone for February.
An underground layer of water-bearing permeable rock.
Can be a source of groundwater.
Often tapped by wells.
A thin, knife-like ridge of rock.
Formed by two glaciers eroding opposite sides of a mountain.
A common feature in glaciated landscapes.
A low-lying area of land.
Often surrounded by higher ground.
Can be a site of sediment deposition.
A landform alongside a body of water.
Consists of loose particles such as sand, pebbles, or shells.
Where the land meets the sea.
A common rock-forming mineral of the mica family.
Dark-colored and shiny.
Found in igneous and metamorphic rocks.
A clastic sedimentary rock composed of large, angular fragments.
Unlike conglomerate, its fragments are sharp.
Forms from the cementation of rubble.
A cryptocrystalline form of silica.
Includes varieties like agate and onyx.
Has a waxy luster.
A soft, porous form of limestone.
Composed of the shells of tiny marine organisms.
Used as a writing tool.
A steep conical hill of loose pyroclastic fragments.
Forms around a volcanic vent.
One of the simplest types of volcanoes.
The tendency of a mineral to break along flat planar surfaces.
A useful characteristic for mineral identification.
Perfect or poor, depending on the mineral.
A geological structure where parallel columns form in a rock body.
Common in basalt flows and other volcanic rocks.
Devils Tower in Wyoming is a famous example.
A type of stress that squeezes a rock mass.
Causes shortening and thickening of the crust.
Associated with convergent plate boundaries.
Metamorphism caused by heat from a magma intrusion.
Occurs near the border of a magma body.
Forms a halo of metamorphic rock.
The extended perimeter of a continent.
Covered by relatively shallow seas.
Rich in marine life and resources.
A solid material whose constituents are arranged in a highly ordered microscopic structure.
A key feature of many minerals.
Has a repeating pattern.
A volcanic pipe of brecciated rock.
Formed by a violent, gas-charged volcanic eruption.
Can be a source of diamonds.
An elongated hill of glacial drift.
Shaped like an inverted spoon.
Points in the direction of glacial flow.
Relating to or caused by wind.
Describes deposits like sand dunes and loess.
A type of geological process.
Broad, gentle warping of the Earth's crust.
Causes uplift or subsidence.
Can lead to the formation of large domes or basins.
A long, narrow crack or opening.
Can be a vent for a volcano.
A type of geological fracture.
Relating to a river.
Describes processes or landforms created by streams.
Opposite of glacial.
A hollow rock with an internal cavity lined with crystals.
Often spherical in shape.
Can be cracked open to reveal its beauty.
An older geological theory.
A large-scale depression in the Earth's crust.
Supposedly filled with thick sediments to form mountain belts.
A green mineral of the mica group.
An indicator of marine sedimentary environments.
Often found in greensand formations.
A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock.
Similar to granite, but with more plagioclase feldspar.
A major component of many batholiths.
A soft sulfate mineral.
Used to make plaster and drywall.
A common evaporite mineral.
A complex inosilicate mineral.
A common dark-colored mineral.
Found in igneous and metamorphic rocks.
A period of long-term reduction in the temperature of the Earth's climate.
Results in the expansion of continental ice sheets.
The last one ended about 11,700 years ago.
The process of magma moving into a pre-existing rock formation.
Also refers to the resulting rock body.
A term for igneous rock that cooled underground.
The state of gravitational equilibrium between the Earth's lithosphere and asthenosphere.
Explains why mountains have deep 'roots'.
Relates to the buoyancy of the crust.
A shallow, sediment-filled body of water.
Formed by the melting of a buried block of glacial ice.
A common feature in moraines.
A dome-shaped body of intrusive igneous rock.
Forms from magma that pushes up the overlying layers.
The Henry Mountains of Utah are an example.
A deep-blue metamorphic rock.
Composed primarily of lazurite.
Prized since antiquity for its intense color.
One of the several huge, rigid slabs of the Earth's crust.
In constant motion, driven by convection in the mantle.
The main components of plate tectonics.
A sheet of magma that cuts through existing rock layers.
Can be a few inches to many feet wide.
A type of intrusive igneous rock formation.
An upwelling of abnormally hot rock within the Earth's mantle.
Thought to be the cause of hotspots.
A proposed cause of some volcanism.
The geomorphic process by which soil, sand, and rock move downslope.
Can be a slow creep or a sudden landslide.
A form of erosion.
The process of changing the structure and composition of a rock.
Caused by heat, pressure, or chemical alteration.
Creates metamorphic rocks.
The boundary between the Earth's crust and the mantle.
Short for Mohorovicic discontinuity.
Marks a change in seismic wave velocity.
A bend in rock strata.
Layers are horizontal on either side of a single fold.
A simple type of fold.
A common type of tree.
Not a mineral, but often a source of petrified wood.
A tree known for its strength.
A type of fault movement.
Combines strike-slip and dip-slip motion.
Movement is both horizontal and vertical.
A section of oceanic crust and upper mantle.
Thought to be a piece of oceanic lithosphere obducted onto continental crust.
Provides evidence for plate tectonics.
A geologic period and system of the Paleozoic Era.
Follows the Cambrian Period.
Known for the diversification of marine life.
A plain formed by glacial sediments deposited by meltwater.
Can be found in front of a glacier.
Also known as a sandur.
The study of geographical features at particular times in the geological past.
Looks at the reconstruction of ancient continents.
A sub-discipline of geology.
The study of the record of the Earth's magnetic field in rocks.

Shows how continents have drifted over time.
A dense, coarse-grained igneous rock.
The dominant rock type in the Earth's upper mantle.
The source of basaltic magma.
The last period of the Paleozoic Era.
Ended with the largest mass extinction in Earth's history.
Followed by the Triassic Period.
The current geologic eon.
Means 'visible life' in Greek.
Includes the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic eras.
A gentle slope leading from the base of mountains to a plain.
The area at the foot of a mountain.
The term for the southeastern US region.
A series of tectosilicate minerals within the feldspar group.
A major component of the Earth's crust.
Ranges in composition from albite to anorthite.
A type of igneous rock.
Formed from magma that cooled slowly underground.

A measure of the void spaces in a material.
A factor in how much water a rock can hold.

A physical process.
Describing a rock body that is flat and plate-like.

A geological shape.

A type of basalt.
